Introduction

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by deficient CD18-containing integrins on the surface of leukocytes (particularly neutrophils), impairing leukocyte adhesion to the endothelium.  Patients are at increased risk for recurrent infections and impaired wound healing.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Normally, leukocytes circulate with minimal contact with the endothelium.  When inflammation (eg, infection, injury) occurs, leukocytes must migrate to the site, a process that requires several steps (

figure 1
).  Following phagocytosis of the pathogen, tissue macrophages release inflammatory cytokines that increase the expression of endothelial selectins.  Weak interaction with selectins allows circulating leukocytes to roll along the endothelium.  Increased contact with the endothelium activates integrins (heterodimers of alpha- and beta-protein chains) on the surface of leukocytes.  Integrins facilitate leukocyte adhesion to the endothelium, followed by extravasation and transmigration to the site of inflammation.



A defect in any one of these adhesion molecules can impair leukocyte adhesion and extravasation, leading to LAD.  Although multiple types of LAD exist, type I is the most common and occurs due to an autosomal recessive mutation in the gene that encodes CD18, the beta-protein chain found in many integrins.  Because LAD is an autosomal recessive disorder, a family history is the primary risk factor.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of LAD depends on the degree of deficiency of CD18-containing integrins.  Patients with severe deficiency classically present with delayed umbilical cord separation (ie, age >3 weeks) due to impaired wound healing.  However, patients with mild to moderate deficiency can have normal umbilical cord separation but present with recurrent skin (eg, cellulitis, omphalitis) and mucosal (eg, gingival) infections in early childhood.  Gastrointestinal and respiratory tract infections are also common.  Infections are typically bacterial or fungal; increased susceptibility to viral infections has not been observed.  Severe gingivitis and periodontitis occur in nearly all patients, leading to the eventual loss of all teeth.



Because neutrophil adhesion and extravasation are impaired, there is no purulence at the site of infection, even in severe infections.  Moreover, infectious fluids (eg, pleural effusion) lack leukocytes on microscopic examination.  Because neutrophils are also involved in the initial phases of wound healing (

figure 2
), patients also experience delayed healing after surgery or trauma.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected LAD (eg, history of delayed umbilical cord separation, recurrent nonpurulent infections), laboratory testing should be performed:



  • Complete blood count (CBC):  The CBC shows baseline leukocytosis and neutrophilia that increase markedly during infections due to impaired mobilization.  Absolute lymphocyte and monocyte counts are typically normal.
  • Bacterial culture:  Infections are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and gram-negative bacilli.
  • Biopsy of infected tissue:  Biopsy shows inflammatory infiltrate without neutrophils.


The diagnosis is confirmed with flow cytometry confirming deficient CD18 expression on the surface of leukocytes.  Genetic testing may be considered to identify the exact mutation.

Differential diagnosis



LAD has unique clinical and laboratory features (eg, recurrent nonpurulent skin, mucosal infections with leukocytosis) that often distinguish it from other immunodeficiencies.  Other conditions to consider in the differential diagnosis include:



  • Chronic granulomatous disease:  An X-linked recessive genetic condition, chronic granulomatous disease is characterized by impaired neutrophil function (ie, superoxide formation, intracellular killing).  Patients present with recurrent infections with catalase-positive bacteria (eg, S aureus, Serratia marcescens) with purulence and granuloma formation.
  • ChÃ©diak-Higashi syndrome:  An autosomal recessive disorder, ChÃ©diak-Higashi syndrome is characterized by impaired lysosomal trafficking.  Patients can present with recurrent skin infections such as LAD, but they also have oculocutaneous albinism and neurologic abnormalities.
  • Adenosine deaminase deficiency:  An autosomal recessive genetic condition, adenosine deaminase deficiency is characterized by a deficiency of mature B and T cells (ie, marked lymphopenia on CBC).  Patients develop severe infections and failure to thrive.

Management



The management of LAD involves infection prevention (eg, careful hygiene, routine vaccinations) and systemic antibiotic therapy.  When possible, systemic antibiotic therapy should be guided by culture and sensitivity data to avoid antibiotic resistance.  Prophylactic antibiotics are indicated in some cases.  Patients with mild to moderate deficiency of CD18-containing integrins can survive into adulthood with prompt diagnosis and treatment of infections.



Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is curative but indicated only in severe cases due to associated risks.  Without HSCT, patients with severe disease typically die in infancy.

Summary
